data.value: Suppose we have (N+1) samples of f at the positions x_0, x_1, ..., x_N. Then an N-point Newton-Cotes formula for the integral between x_0 and x_N is:

\int_{x_0}^{x_N} f(x)dx = \Delta x \sum_{i=0}^{N} a_i f(x_i)
+ B_N (\Delta x)^{N+2} f^{N+1} (\xi)
If the samples are equally-spaced and N is even, then the error term is
Normally, the Newton-Cotes rules are used on smaller integration regions and a composite rule is used to return the total integral.
The integer order for equally-spaced data or the relative positions of the samples with the first sample at 0 and the last at N, where N+1 is the length of
. N is the order of the Newton-Cotes integration.
Set to 1 to enforce equally spaced data.
1-D array of weights to apply to the function at the provided sample positions.
Return weights and error coefficient for Newton-Cotes integration.
